question_text: A 58-year-old man is evaluated for a rash on the right side of his abdomen that developed over the past 2 weeks.
question_stem: Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
critique: The patient's skin finding is consistent with the erythema migrans lesion (Option B) that characterizes the early phase of infection with the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi following an Ixodes tick bite. The early localized rash of Lyme disease generally occurs within the first month of infection at the site of the tick bite, often the belt line, inguinal region, popliteal fossa, or axilla. The rash expands over the course of days to weeks, characteristically developing an area of central clearing with expansion that leads to a “bullseye” appearance (as in this patient). Some patients may have a small area of necrosis at the center of the rash, although that finding is less common.
